--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !! 
--- BDT                      : <Train> elapsed time: [1;31m16.6 sec[0m

--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !!

--- IdTransformation         :   25 : DER_deltaeta_jet_jet        : 1.690e-02
--- IdTransformation         :   26 : PRI_jet_subleading_phi      : 1.687e-02
--- IdTransformation         :   27 : PRI_met_phi                 : 4.897e-03
--- IdTransformation         :   28 : PRI_tau_phi                 : 4.232e-03
--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !! 
--- BDT                      : <Train> elapsed time: [1;31m18 sec[0m                              
--- BDT                      : <Train> average number of nodes (w/o pruning) : 30
--- BDT                      : End of training

--- BDT                      : The following options are set:
--- BDT                      : - By User:
--- BDT                      :     V: "True" [Verbose output (short form of "VerbosityLevel" below - overrides the latter one)]
--- BDT                      :     H: "True" [Print method-specific help message]
--- BDT                      :     CreateMVAPdfs: "True" [Create PDFs for classifier outputs (signal and background)]
--- BDT                      :     NTrees: "300" [Number of trees in the forest]
--- BDT                      :     MaxDepth: "5" [Max depth of the decision tree allowed]
--- BDT                      :     MinNodeSize: "2%" [Minimum percentage of training events required in a leaf node (default: Classification: 5%, Regression: 0.2%)]

--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !!

--- BDT                      : - By User:

--- BDT                      :     H: "True" [Print method-specific help message]
--- BDT                      :     CreateMVAPdfs: "True" [Create PDFs for classifier outputs (signal and background)]
--- BDT                      :     NTrees: "300" [Number of trees in the forest]
--- BDT                      :     MaxDepth: "5" [Max depth of the decision tree allowed]
--- BDT                      :     MinNodeSize: "2%" [Minimum percentage of training events required in a leaf node (default: Classification: 5%, Regression: 0.2%)]

--- BDT                      :     BoostType: "Grad" [Boosting type for the trees in the forest (note: AdaCost is still experimental)]

--- BDT                      :     VarTransform: "None" [List of variable transformations performed before training, e.g., "D_Background,P_Signal,G,N_AllClasses" for: "Decorrelation, PCA-transformation, Gaussianisation, Normalisation, each for the given class of events ('AllClasses' denotes all events of all classes, if no class indication is given, 'All' is assumed)"]
--- BDT                      :     IgnoreNegWeightsInTraining: "False" [Events with negative weights are ignored in the training (but are included for testing and performance evaluation)]

--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !! 
--- BDT                      : <Train> elapsed time: [1;31m17 sec[0m                              
--- BDT                      : <Train> average number of nodes (w/o pruning) : 31
--- BDT                      : End of training                                              
--- BDT                      : Elapsed time for training with 24999 events: [1;31m17.3 sec[0m

--- BDT                      :     MaxDepth: "5" [Max depth of the decision tree allowed]
--- BDT                      :     MinNodeSize: "2%" [Minimum percentage of training events required in a leaf node (default: Classification: 5%, Regression: 0.2%)]

--- BDT                      :     BoostType: "Grad" [Boosting type for the trees in the forest (note: AdaCost is still experimental)]
--- BDT                      :     UseBaggedBoost: "True" [Use only a random subsample of all events for growing the trees in each boost iteration.]
--- BDT                      :     Shrinkage: "3.000000e-01" [Learning rate for GradBoost algorithm]

--- BDT                      :     IgnoreNegWeightsInTraining: "False" [Events with negative weights are ignored in the training (but are included for testing and performance evaluation)]
--- BDT                      :     AdaBoostR2Loss: "Quadratic" [Type of Loss function in AdaBoostR2]
--- BDT                      :     AdaBoostBeta: "5.000000e-01" [Learning rate  for AdaBoost algorithm]
--- BDT                      :     UseRandomisedTrees: "False" [Determine at each node splitting the cut variable only as the best out of a random subset of variables (like in RandomForests)]
--- BDT                      :     UseNvars: "5" [Size of the subset of variables used with RandomisedTree option]
--- BDT                      :     UsePoissonNvars: "True" [Interpret "UseNvars" not as fixed number but as mean of a Possion distribution in each split with RandomisedTree option]
--- BDT                      :     BaggedSampleFraction: "5.000000e-01" [Relative size of bagged event sample to original size of the data sample (used whenever bagging is used (i.e. UseBaggedBoost, Bagging,)]
--- BDT                      :     UseYesNoLeaf: "True" [Use Sig or Bkg categories, or the purity=S/(S+B) as classification of the leaf node -> Real-AdaBoost]

--- IdTransformation         :   27 : PRI_met_phi                 : 4.897e-03
--- IdTransformation         :   28 : PRI_tau_phi                 : 4.232e-03
--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !!

--- BDT                      :     AdaBoostR2Loss: "Quadratic" [Type of Loss function in AdaBoostR2]
--- BDT                      :     AdaBoostBeta: "5.000000e-01" [Learning rate  for AdaBoost algorithm]
--- BDT                      :     UseRandomisedTrees: "False" [Determine at each node splitting the cut variable only as the best out of a random subset of variables (like in RandomForests)]
--- BDT                      :     UseNvars: "5" [Size of the subset of variables used with RandomisedTree option]
--- BDT                      :     UsePoissonNvars: "True" [Interpret "UseNvars" not as fixed number but as mean of a Possion distribution in each split with RandomisedTree option]
--- BDT                      :     BaggedSampleFraction: "5.000000e-01" [Relative size of bagged event sample to original size of the data sample (used whenever bagging is used (i.e. UseBaggedBoost, Bagging,)]
--- BDT                      :     UseYesNoLeaf: "True" [Use Sig or Bkg categories, or the purity=S/(S+B) as classification of the leaf node -> Real-AdaBoost]
--- BDT                      :     NegWeightTreatment: "InverseBoostNegWeights" [How to treat events with negative weights in the BDT training (particular the boosting) : IgnoreInTraining;  Boost With inverse boostweight; Pair events with negative and positive weights in traning sample and *annihilate* them (experimental!)]
--- BDT                      :     Css: "1.000000e+00" [AdaCost: cost of true signal selected signal]
--- BDT                      :     Cts_sb: "1.000000e+00" [AdaCost: cost of true signal selected bkg]
--- BDT                      :     Ctb_ss: "1.000000e+00" [AdaCost: cost of true bkg    selected signal]
--- BDT                      :     Cbb: "1.000000e+00" [AdaCost: cost of true bkg    selected bkg ]

--- BDT                      :     DoBoostMonitor: "False" [Create control plot with ROC integral vs tree number]
--- BDT                      :     UseFisherCuts: "False" [Use multivariate splits using the Fisher criterion]

--- IdTransformation         :   27 : PRI_met_phi                 : 4.897e-03
--- IdTransformation         :   28 : PRI_tau_phi                 : 4.232e-03
--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467

--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !!

--- IdTransformation         :   29 : PRI_lep_phi                 : 2.905e-03
--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !! 
--- BDT                      : <Train> elapsed time: [1;31m17 sec[0m                              
--- BDT                      : <Train> average number of nodes (w/o pruning) : 30
--- BDT                      : End of training                                              
--- BDT                      : Elapsed time for training with 24999 events: [1;31m17.3 sec[0m         
--- BDT                      : Create MVA output for classification on training sample
--- BDT                      : Evaluation of BDT on training sample (24999 events)
--- BDT                      : Elapsed time for evaluation of 24999 events: [1;31m1.29 sec[0m       
--- BDT_PDFSig               : Validation result for PDF "BDT_tr_S": 
--- BDT_PDFSig               :     chi2/ndof(!=0) = 0.0/100 = 0.00 (Prob = 1.00)
--- BDT_PDFSig               :     #bins-found(#expected-bins) deviating > [1,2,3,6] sigmas: [0(31),0(4),0(0),0(0)]

--- DataSetFactory           :  (and equals the number of events (entries) given for class=0 )

--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !!

--- IdTransformation         : ----------------------------------------------------
--- Factory                  :  
--- Factory                  : Train all methods for Classification ...
--- Factory                  : Train method: BDT for Classification
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : [1mH e l p   f o r   M V A   m e t h o d   [ BDT ] :[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Short description:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Boosted Decision Trees are a collection of individual decision
--- BDT                      : trees which form a multivariate classifier by (weighted) majority 
--- BDT                      : vote of the individual trees. Consecutive decision trees are  
--- BDT                      : trained using the original training data set with re-weighted 
--- BDT                      : events. By default, the AdaBoost method is employed, which gives 
--- BDT                      : events that were misclassified in the previous tree a larger 
--- BDT                      : weight in the training of the following tree.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Decision trees are a sequence of binary splits of the data sample
--- BDT                      : using a single descriminant variable at a time. A test event 
--- BDT                      : ending up after the sequence of left-right splits in a final 
--- BDT                      : ("leaf") node is classified as either signal or background
--- BDT                      : depending on the majority type of training events in that node.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance optimisation:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : By the nature of the binary splits performed on the individual
--- BDT                      : variables, decision trees do not deal well with linear correlations
--- BDT                      : between variables (they need to approximate the linear split in
--- BDT                      : the two dimensional space by a sequence of splits on the two 
--- BDT                      : variables individually). Hence decorrelation could be useful 
--- BDT                      : to optimise the BDT performance.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : [1m--- Performance tuning via configuration options:[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The two most important parameters in the configuration are the  
--- BDT                      : minimal number of events requested by a leaf node as percentage of the 
--- BDT                      :    number of training events (option "MinNodeSize"  replacing the actual number 
--- BDT                      :  of events "nEventsMin" as given in earlier versions
--- BDT                      : If this number is too large, detailed features 
--- BDT                      : in the parameter space are hard to be modelled. If it is too small, 
--- BDT                      : the risk to overtrain rises and boosting seems to be less effective
--- BDT                      :   typical values from our current expericience for best performance  
--- BDT                      :   are between 0.5(%) and 10(%) 
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The default minimal number is currently set to 
--- BDT                      :    max(20, (N_training_events / N_variables^2 / 10)) 
--- BDT                      : and can be changed by the user.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : The other crucial parameter, the pruning strength ("PruneStrength"),
--- BDT                      : is also related to overtraining. It is a regularisation parameter 
--- BDT                      : that is used when determining after the training which splits 
--- BDT                      : are considered statistically insignificant and are removed. The
--- BDT                      : user is advised to carefully watch the BDT screen output for
--- BDT                      : the comparison between efficiencies obtained on the training and
--- BDT                      : the independent test sample. They should be equal within statistical
--- BDT                      : errors, in order to minimize statistical fluctuations in different samples.
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : <Suppress this message by specifying "!H" in the booking option>
--- BDT                      : [1m================================================================[0m
--- BDT                      : 
--- BDT                      : Begin training
--- BDT                      :  found and suggest the following possible pre-selection cuts 
--- BDT                      : as option DoPreselection was not used, these cuts however will not be performed, but the training will see the full sample
--- BDT                      : <InitEventSample> For classification trees, 
--- BDT                      :  the effective number of backgrounds is scaled to match 
--- BDT                      :  the signal. Othersise the first boosting step would do 'just that'!
--- BDT                      : re-normlise events such that Sig and Bkg have respective sum of weights = 1
--- BDT                      :   sig->sig*1.46501ev. bkg->bkg*1.46501ev.
--- BDT                      : #events: (reweighted) sig: 12499.5 bkg: 12499.5
--- BDT                      : #events: (unweighted) sig: 8532 bkg: 16467
--- BDT                      : Training 300 Decision Trees ... patience please
--- BinaryTree               : The minimal node size MinNodeSize=2 fMinNodeSize=2% is translated to an actual number of events = 251.52 for the training sample size of 12576
--- BinaryTree               : Note: This number will be taken as absolute minimum in the node, 
--- BinaryTree               :       in terms of 'weighted events' and unweighted ones !!
